article_title: Mayes County sex offender suing to keep living in home near school
article_text:
PRYOR — A Mayes County sex offender has sued the District Attorney's Office and Pryor Police Department, claiming that they are applying a law retroactively and preventing him from living in his home near a school.

Gary Hunt, 71, was convicted on a federal child-porn possession charge in August 2008 and was sentenced to 63 months in prison, documents show.

After his release from custody in August, he was told by law enforcement that he could not live in his home in Pryor because it is within 2,000 feet of Jefferson Elementary School, states a petition for declaratory judgment filed by Hunt's attorney, Gerald Lee.

The Sex Offenders Registration Act makes it unlawful for any registered sex offender to live within 2,000 feet of any school. But that section of the act became effective in November 2003, and Hunt lived in the residence from November 2000 until January 2009, which was prior to the statute's enactment, the petition indicates.

Hunt claims that the state's threat to enforce the act violates the U.S. and Oklahoma Constitutions' prohibitions against laws that are applied retroactively, documents show.

Hunt, who is living elsewhere in the county, can't buy another home because he has health problems and is permanently disabled, his attorney said.

Hunt derives his income from state retirement and Social Security benefits, documents show.

Lee said last week that although it is "not exactly on point," a 2013 Oklahoma Supreme Court case speaks in part to his client's case.

The high court, in examining the public sex offender registry laws for a Texas man who moved to Oklahoma, found retroactive application of revised sex-offender registration rules violated a state constitution provision against laws applied retroactively.

Marny Hill is an assistant district attorney in District 12, which serves Mayes, Rogers and Craig counties.

"While we can't take the house away or force him to sell the house, ... we can tell him that he's prohibited from living in that area due to the sex offender registration laws," Hill said.
